instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Hello. 

Mac <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> doesn't turns on. 20v 0.05A with battery, 5v 0.05A without battery.
Found short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SOCPMU</SIGNAL> (<CAPACITOR>C7805</CAPACITOR>), after i changed cap - short is gone. 
Now PPBUS - 12.3v, 
         <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
         <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> - 0.4v
Other voltages are missing, so no DFU as well. With <RESISTOR>R5750</RESISTOR> removed - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> is 0v and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SOCPMU</SIGNAL> is 1,5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> comes from <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>, but there are no enable signals for this chip, <SIGNAL>P5V_3V3G3H_EN</SIGNAL> comes from <SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL>, and it comes from <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>. Changed <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, no changes. 
         Schematic shows there are 3 <SIGNAL>LDO_IN</SIGNAL> for <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>: <SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> (missing) <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> (missing) and only <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> is present. So as i understand <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is not powered and not creating voltage for T2
          Im not sure which chip is responsible for creating SLPS2R signals, is it <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>? Looks like im stuck here...
Thanks for help in advance!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
"there are 3 <SIGNAL>LDO_IN</SIGNAL> for <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>: <SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> (missing) <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> (missing) and only <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> is present. So as i understand <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is not powered"
Wrong understood!
<SIGNAL>LDO_IN</SIGNAL> are the points where PMU connects to LDO0-3 outputs to supervise them.
PMU generate these 3 LDO-3 voltages, powered from  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> , through <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR>; did you check if the resistor is good?
<SIGNAL>LDO_RTC</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>VOUT_RTC</SIGNAL> must appear at same time.

Check for short at all <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> surrounding coils, L78xx.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
You right, <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> was blown, 350k. There was only 1,5V on second pin. Now laptop works. Thank you so much! Really appreciate your help!
    So there was no power for <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, is it correct?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Exactly!
You've went for hard job first, changing <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
Possibly was bad, if <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> found open; but very easy to check with a diode mode reading...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Thanks again for helping and explaining.
